narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to get the information necessary from a reading without having to read word for word. This class was very reading intensive, so this skill really helped me get through the readings. I also believe that my writing got better during this time as the professor gave useful feedback on our written assignments.

It was interesting to learn about medieval Islam (which I knew nothing of before taking the class) from the perspective of the marginalized. Usually when studying a topic, the history of rulers and innovators is covered first, but in this class we started with the destitute, the disabled, and the enslaved.

I gained a great amount of unique and nuanced insight into the lives of people living on the margins of society during the early modern historical period in the Middle East. I had never taken a class on this historical period before so it was very beneficial for me. Professor Yadgar gave us a lot of information on very interesting and unique aspects of life during this historical period.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strength: great discussion. Interesting readings that weren't too complicated and hard to read. 
Weakness: Not everyone participated, so most of the time the discussion was just between the professor and 2 or 3 students. 

Improvement: Not sure what steps the professor can take, but it would've benefitted everyone if the rest of the students were encouraged more to speak up.
Really interesting topic! 9:25 Monday is just not the best time to have a super engaging seminar

The readings for this course were engaging and well-selected. Occasionally a reading was unusually long and difficult to understand, and we didn't end up discussing it very much, but this only happened one or two times. The discussions always began with a bit of historical context before we delved into analysis of the texts. Professor Yadgar was good at asking questions that sparked conversation.
This was a really good class, overall. it covered many different aspects of marginality in Medieval Islamic societies and included many interesting readings.
I really do not think this course could be improved. Professor Yadgar did a great job leading the discussions during class and he made sure all the students were very engaged throughout the class.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, if you really want to learn about Medieval Islam by looking at how the Medieval Muslim communities treated "outsiders" then you should take this class.

This was a great class. If you're remotely interested in the material, it's a lot of fun to delve into and we definitely laughed a fair number of times. The structure makes a lot of sense and the readings are engaging.

I would definitely recommend this class to another student. It is a pretty niche topic - marginal groups in Medieval Islamic societies - however, it was a really fascinating class that discussed marginality in many different forms. The class included diverse and critical readings and engaged with a lot of different societies and histories. Professor Yadgar was great and was good at facilitating discussion.

I would certainly recommend this course to another student for the following reasons: 1) The material is very interesting and not commonly studied 2) Professor Yadgar is a great professor and provides great information on how to become a better historian, writer, and researcher.
